Most of these limitations are a result of limited health care resources. In many Sub-Saharan African nations there are less than 0.4 physicians and 1 bed for every 1000 population, and health expenditures as a percentage of gross domestic product hardly exceed 5%.
35 This situation is even worse in Ebola-stricken nations because their health systems are plagued by diverse levels of dysfunction, including the inability to maintain adequate infection control. Poor infection control mechanisms have led to the infection and depletion of the nations' already scarce health workforce.
